												If you're looking for a fun addition to the Batman franchise, I'd recommend it. If you're looking for a good platformer, hold off on it. For now. Batman™: Arkham Origins Blackgate adds a good story upon Arkham Origins' original one that will keep any Batman-fan interrested to the end. However, in terms of gameplay, it's not too good. Not for a Batman game nor a platformer. The Good:· An interresting story that takes place after Arkham Origins and before Arkham Asylum, set mostly in Blackgate Prison.· Fun and different take on the Arkham storyline. With drawn comicbook-esque cinematics and 2.5D gameplay it offers an entirely different way of playing as Batman. Using Batman's gadgets in 2D is surprisingly entertaining.· Collectibles give fans a reason to return to the game after completion, albeit very linear. That being said...The Bad:· ... the game plays a bit too linear for an Arkham game. The combat and platforming feel a bit too stiff and at points even forced. The series is known for, among others, its Free Flow combat system. Don't expect to see Free Flow combat here. There is combat in the game that looks a little bit like the combat in Arkham Asylum, but it plays stiff and clunky.· Confusing and overly-guided platforming combined with reasonably frustrating stealth gameplay will definately take some getting used to (for example, Batman will switch from one platform in the foreground to another platform in the background using the Batclaw and there is no option to look around while in vents).The Ugly:· For a port its pretty reasonable, with smoothened egdes and overall a slightly better quality but characters will still feel stiff and the environments at times a bit repetetive or downright boring.Final Verdict:Batman™: Arkham Origins Blackgate is a fun game to play through if you're a big Batman fan, but platformer-lovers won't really find anything new or surprisingly interresting. Are you interrested in the game for its story, or are you looking for the series' innovative gameplay? That question is one this review answers.7/10.

												So at first, I didn't know what Arkham Origins - Blackgate was. I looked at some reviews and there a mix of good and bad. Alot of people said that the combat was bad, detective mode and visuals were horrible. As an arkham fan, playing arkham asylym first and enjoying it very so, I decided to give blackgate a chance and see for myself how it was after beating arkham origins.So the game takes place three monthes after Batman Arkham Origins.The basic story is you got a blackgate prison out break, and Batman is trying to stop this outbreak by gaining control of the 3 blocks the prison is divided in by bringing back power to each block. Each block is controlled by a villian. Arkham Wing - Penguin, Administration Building - The Joker, and Industrial Building - Black Mask. Note there is also Soloman Grundy, Deadshot and Catwoman in the game, and you interact with them along the way. The game offers a bit of a choice as you can kind of go after The Joker, Penguin or Black Mask in any order.This does give a new way an arkham game could work, as in all the other arkham games the order in which you chase your villians changes as the story goes on. (Side quests don't count.) There are side quests you can do in this game, but it feels a big task in doing them, and not very fun like in the other arkham games.So let me tell you some things about the combat. Me personally, I didn't find the combat bad, at times I did like it. However, it could use quite a bit of work. First of all, it is a 2.5D game, as in its a 2D Sidescroller game where you can only move left and right, but you're moving around in a 3D World. This already gives you a sense of why people are not liking the combat. The combat in the other arkham games were more free flow and fast paced, where as in arkham blackgate, its restricting, annoying and slow. By restricting I mean you can only fight enemies who are close to you, and fighting off other enemies requires you to jump over the one closest to you, and make your way more up with enemies farther. The controls aren't good as they're are unresponsive and kind of dumb. Prefferably its better to play with a control for this game as the controls are better. It almost pains me to play the game as it more feels like a task. The map itself is very annoying as you can get lost so many times and you're basically spending hours just trying to get to your main point. The map you get to navigate your way around blackgate is confusing as it tries to put a 3D like map in flat like form. On top of that, you need to find upgrades in this map which can also be a pain, as in if you don't the boss battles can be unbeatable. So far for the boss battles, Penguin being the hardest as in one of his guards spot you, they litterly shoot you to death which takes about 2 seconds resulting in you dieing in the process. Not only is that hard, but its even harder as you're in a small area, and to get the guards away from penguin you have to give distractions, and they see you constantly. On top of that, there are drones that scout out the area and shoot on sight which results in a automatic death.The Catwoman boss battle was a bit challenging as you have to time your countering and attacks 100% accuatley and perfectly. Gettingn hit twice results in a automatic death, and there isn't a checkpoint or anything in the battle as its constant dodging every second for like two minutes. It may not seem that hard, but once you get there I wouldn't be surpirsed if you saw some people did it on youtube. Now keep in my mind, this game was originally designed to be on a 3DS/PS Vita. Armature Studies gave a port to give the arkham fans an original feel as all arkham games are for the console (originally made by rocksteady). However, if a game is deisgned for the 3DS/PS Vita, that same game shouldn't have the same design on console/pc versions. if you do, you get all of what I said before, annoying combat, bad maps, annoying controls, it works but is almost unenjoyable, and it's task to play.I don't want to reccomend or not reccomend the game. As an arkham fan the story was decent. Nothing special. Explains a little of what happened between Batman Origins and arkham asylum. So, I will say this. Get this game when its on sale, as its worth the price of 5 bucks. The game itself isn't worth the 20, and I thought this as soon as I actually got into the game.What I suggest Rocksteady to do is make a game that is actually, a sequel to Arkham Origins after they conclude the arkham series with Arkham knight. This game was supposed to be designed to be like that, hence, why it has the name "origins" in the title. However, i think its honnestly a bad idea to do this and design the game itself to be on hand-held consoles, and then to be later ported on to regualr consoles. In my opnion, its a bad idea.Lets hope rocksteady can correct this mistake and give us a real arkham game like blackgate, but redesigned for consoles. Overall, the game deserves a7/10

												I finished up Arkham Origins and lucked into a really cheap copy of AO: Blackgate at roughly the same time. Blackgate is a 2.5D side-scrolling beat-'em-up with a few puzzles thrown in. The story is told through motion-comic-style cutscenes with full voice-acting and it revolves around riots that take place at Blackgate sometime apparently not long after the events of Origins. Black Mask, Penguin, and Joker have all taken control of a section of the prison and Batman has to go in and rescue hostages and take down the bad guys in his inimitable Batman way.Sadly, the gameplay itself is sorely lacking. Armature Studios made an effort to translate the Arkham series' signature free-flow combat to a 2.5D game but it doesn't quite work. As you see from the image below, the game is fond of tossing upwards of 5-8 opponents at Batman simultaneously; this level of opposition is non-problematic in the regular Arkham games because Batman is free to move around at will and target any of his opponents at any time. Here, the Darkknight Detective's movements are restricted to left and right and the game determines his target based on which enemy happens to be closest and in the direction he's currently facing. This makes tactically targeting specific enemies needlessly difficult, especially when facing knife- or stun-baton-wielding foes, which require certain actions to eliminate. In small groups the regular villains aren't too difficult to handle, but when the game presents you with multiple groups of antagonists at once, things can get hairy.However, the boss fights are the epitome of everything that you hate about the concept of "boss fight" in a game. Some of them, like Black Mask and Bronze Tiger, are pretty straightforward, but the Penguin, Joker, and Catwoman battles get progressively more irritating as you fight through multiple stages that require very specific attack strategies to defeat. I actually quit the game before finishing the Catwoman fight because for some absurd reason the counters don't work the same way in this conflict as they do in the rest of the game; the second and third stages of this fight require you to counter her attacks before you can go on the offensive, and because the controls for countering appear to be virtually unresponsive in this fight, I gave up after 9-10 attempts. Maybe if you're more dexterous than me, you'll have better luck.The other aspects of the game are merely okay. The game includes a detective mode, like its big brothers, so Batman can scan the environment for ways to get around and collectibles. There are suit pieces that can be collected and different Batsuits can confer bonuses. For example, the "Beware the Batman" suit that you get by having an Arkham Origins save on your computer provides a 50% armor bonus against gunfire. A Blackest Night suit (grants invulnerability to most forms of damage) is available by collecting the pieces in-game (you'll have to get about 95% of the way through the game to get all of the pieces so it's not game-breaking) and another (Zero Year) that you get from having a WBID login. You can only collect one of the other suits per playthrough, depending on the order in which you defeat the game's bosses. There are also detective cases to solve, which essentially involves going everywhere it's possible to go and scanning all areas with your Detective Vision until you find all of the clues associated with a specific case (these just basically provide a minimal amount of additional insight into the villains' activities just before or during the events of the game). You'll spend a lot of time doing Armature's version of the crypto-sequencer, which means matching a sequence of three numbers until you get the correct combination to unlock a door or device.You won't be able to get every collectible in each area the first time you go through it because, as in the other Arkham games, some require you to have access to gadgets that you have to acquire as you progress through the story. That's not so unusual, but navigating through the different areas of the prison using the in-game map is quite a chore because it often appears that you can head in a particular direction, only to come across a dead end or switchback and the maps are really just cleverly-constructed labyrinths. At least a few hours of my playtime I can probably chalk up to wandering around the cell blocks and industrial areas, trying to reach an exit or some other specific landmark that was gratuitously problematic to locate.Everything looks good here and the voice-acting is first-rate, so there are no issues on the presentation side, but in the final analysis, this game is remarkably inferior to its full-fledged, 3D brethren. The action is mediocre, the puzzles aren't really puzzles at all, the boss fights are infuriating, and the story is really the only interesting thing about it. I spent about 19 hours playing but if you're the kind of OCD person who needs to get every achievement, you'll have to play three times so you could easily get the same amount of mileage out of this as you did from Arkham Origins. By then you'll probably wish you'd never heard of Batman, let alone this particular game.

												While a Batman metroidvania sounds really, really good in principle, this game is probably the worst implementation of it I could imagine? The 2.5D nature makes it really hard to tell what you can and can't interact with, given that you'll be going in and out of the background in various rooms, and the combat system being a stripped down, less-controllable version of the Arkham games' fighting means that enemy encounters are a slog rather than an easily skipped or shot target when traversing older rooms. The enemies can be in three dimensions, but you cannot move in them, so if someone is not quite in the melee yet, or is pushed aside somehow, well, enjoy dropping combos as you want to hit them. (Similarly, it makes targeting whoever has the assault rifle a real bear, because guess what the lock-on doesn't prioritize in this game like the others?)Another thing that should be mentioned is that while they try really, really hard to make sure the controls keep continuity with the other games, this is adapted from a 3DS/Vita game, which means that some very, very strange controls are in place, and let's not even get into how Detective Mode is basically just "see vision cones because where enemies are looking is not always clear". To actually look at things, you need to turn on DM, then hold the button down to bring up a magnifying-glass reticle, then shift it with one stick while hoping anything at all on your screen is something Batman will interact with. These objects are, by and large, not highlighted (or sometimes even hinted at in any fashion), so just pull out the ol' magnifier whenever you hit a dead end and hope that's the right response, not "oops I needed to look at a grate two rooms back so I could open it".Let me be fair to the game and give it some honest praise: it seems to be somewhat non-linear. There are three seperate wings of the prison you need to get into, and each is its own distinct area with a gadget that'll help you progress/an upgrade to pass more security clearance, which will also open up new secrets in the others, so that's cool. It's just that the actual traversal and exploration is a massive pain due to the environments being unclear in what's set dressing and what's interactable, and the combat being a large slog for back-and-forth travel. (It doesn't even give you XP or anything like in the other Arkham titles, so it is seriously just time-wasting filler. Your health regenerates slowly out of combat.)I seriously can't recommend this game to anyone unless you really, really want to see Batman do the Samus thing, or finally want an Arkham game that lets you play dress-up without needing to NG+ it. It's not particularly fun and so, so many games on Steam scratch the gameplay itch for this genre better.

												TLDR = I love the Arkham series. This game sucks.I went into this with very low expectations, and I'm still disappointed.Gameplay: Honestly, you have to scan EVERYTHING, or else you'll miss something. Every few feet you run, you have to hold LB, move the circle around the screen, just to make sure there isn't simple tiny 5 pixel big thing that you're supposed to scan. Every now and then you run into a few guys to fight. You then run back and forth throughout the whole complex, trying to find that ONE little spot where you're supposed to do something. Some people are calling this Metroidish, in that you need to backtrack... No... Metroid backtracking made sense, and was fun. This is just randomly wandering the same halls over and over again, with very little idea of what to do, scanning everything you can find. It's all one giant monotonously boring grind. Incredibly not fun. It's a chore to play this game.Stealth: Very little stealth in the game, and it's extremely simplistic, and even boring. Later in the game there's some difficult stealth fights, but it's not difficult in a fun way, it's difficult in a "COME ON I'm pushing the button to go up there so DO IT!" kind of way. You just really don't feel like you are the Batman. You feel like you have to find the EXACT right moment to push a certain button. Really lame.Fighting: Not very many fights at all to be honest. For example, the biggest fight in the whole game is about seven thugs... no joke... two are armored, the rest are just regular thugs, one might have a knife. Super simple. The fighting is FAR more simplistic; no specials, don't really use gadgets, just boring. Also, the timing of the counters and hits feels waaaay off. I'm quite good at the Arkham games (100% all of them, two of them twice), and I just can't get the hang of the combat, because it just doesn't feel like they put the time into it, to make it smooth and reliable. Stun a guy and expect to then beat him down? Nope. Game will make you punch the guy next to him. Jump over a stun stick guy and think you'll hit him? Nope. Game makes you hit someone else. Just really bad programming.Story: The story is boring and predictible, and gave me no motivation at all to play. Minor spoilers: It's basically a jailbreak, and you have to fight all the criminals all over again, but there's a plotline where someone higher up has allowed this to happen for reasons (just to have that expected twist, lol).Overall: The game is monotonous. It feels like a constant boring brind. I will beat it, merely because of my love for Batman. I knew going into it that it was a money grab, and I'm still very disappointed.EDIT: It gets worse... There are missable achievements, and they're so missable that you have to completely restart your entire game... The game is also built in a way that you have to play through the whole terrible game three times in order to get 100%. Good games I don't mind doing this for, but badly made game with little to offer? Wow, just so annoyed right now.

This is one of the many parts that gets Simplified. (Other examples include: Stealth sequences, hiding areas, Gadget use and the Detective scanner.) -However, Many people who liked the origal combat system will dislike this.+The Plot is good and the map is heavily influenced by the ongoing story. There are 3 main sections to play in. (These include The Cells blocks, Administration and Industrial.)The best part about these seperate locations is that each one has been captured by 3 of Batman's Biggest villains...Black Mask, Joker and Penguin. This works very well with the story and the feeling of liberating each one is great! Although it isn't as large and "free" as the other games.+First Appearance of Catwoman in the Arkham Storyline. Amd many new characters are introduced +The Cutscene illustration is amazing! Its like watching a cartoon or a slideshow in the Batman universe. Its very unique when compared to the other games and its Art-style is a welcome addition to the series. They do seem a bit lazy in parts and switch pictures rather than a fluid scene. This wasnt a big issue for me however.+The Boss battles are mostly great and provide a respectful difficulty spike in various environements. Guards everywhere with flamethrowers equip Vs gargoyle-hopping stealth sections are a great mix!+Many Unlockable suits and upgrades provided some reasons for replayability, you wont get everything all your first playthrough either. 												Batman Arkham Origins Blackgate is an interesting Batman game. It does things a bit different than the newer Batman games. If I had to make a comparison Arkham Asylum would be closest as far as the gameplay is concerned, because this one also plays like a Metroidvania game, except that you play it on a 2.5D pane this time. So the camera will shift to other angles depending on your location. And because of this the controls aren't as tight as they could be. Remember the older Resident Evil games with their stiff movements ? Sometimes you have to move a certain way but have no clue how to move your analog stick; the game doesn't recognize the obvious, natural move you'd normally make and therefore you unintentionally go back and forth sometimes. Infuriating and frustrating. Another thing that also bothered me, in this day and age, was the lack of lip syncing. I can't think of many other games that don't have this feature nowadays. I know it's supposed to be some sort of budget Batman game, but come on, they could've easily used the models from the other games and downgraded them. Sloppy.The game itself is, praise the Lord, pretty good. It works like any other Metroidvania game. I've told you a dozen times about what a Metroidvania game is all about so I hope you remembered it or else look it up somewhere. The 'detective mode' is a feature that was pretty cool, because you have to scan the environments for clues. Find enough of these clues and you'll solve the case. These clues aren't shown on your map so you have to basically scan everything you see. It would've been nice if you could scan on the move instead of having to stand still but that's just me nitpicking I guess.The boss fights are also nice; some of them are easy, other ones are a bit more difficult.Because the game uses several maps instead of one big map like many other Metroidvania games navigation is sometimes hard. Near the end of the game you have to move between all 4 maps regularly and one mission in particular makes you backtrack through several of these environments. The downside is that you can't easily teleport. It wouldn't fit the game, I agree, but surely they could've come up with something. You can only leave a map at the beginning and at the end, and there's no way in between. The map is hard to read so you'll probably get lost every now and then. The fact that you can move into several directions doesn't help either. Unnecessary if you ask me.The game is lengthy, and will take you about 7-12 hours, depending on what you what to collect. That's just right for a game like this. The graphics haven't been upgraded because the characters still have blurry textures. But it still looks nice in motion. Just don't expect the graphics from the previous Batman games.Batman Arkham Origins Blackgate is a fun game, but unfortunately not without its flaws. And despite these flaws it definitely deserves a chance.[Rating: 77/100]

Batman: Arkham Origins - Blackgate Pros & Cons ReviewPros1: Blackgate continues the adventure from Origins; the story taking place mostly in Blackgate Prison as opposed to a large section of Gotham City.2: Comicbook-esque cinematics and 2.5D Metroidvania style gameplay offering an entirely different way to play as the Caped Crusader.3: Collectable Batsuits offers fans a reason to push their skills further and replay the game on harder difficulties to collect them all.Cons1: Combat and Stealth borderlines on overly frustrating; precision moves are next to impossible at times due to the nature of the gameplay.2: Fixed Camera while good for Metroidvania style games doesn’t translate well to Batman’s stealth gameplay; the inability to look around in vents compounds this fact.3: Boss fights are made frustrating by the clunky controls, leading to many retries and in general it can make navigation difficult. Overall: 7/10My thoughts on Batman Arkham Origins - Blackgate,I’ve never been one for platformer style games but I did enjoy this tile; I’m a sucker for collecting things in games and oh boy does this have a bunch of collectables. Among those collectables are cool new Batsuits but unlike others in the Arkham series where it’s just for show some of these suits actually give you a boost to help you out during the course of the campaign. I recommend hunting down “The Darkest Knight” suit as it basically gives you invulnerability. I also loved the comicbook-esque cinematics… It might not be for everyone but for me it reminded me of watching the original animated series way back in the day.Unfortunately, as much as I enjoyed playing the game and taking in it’s cool narrative from a unique perspective it was annoyingly frustrating at times due to its finicky controls. Example, when fighting one or more enemies close together and you use cap stun it won’t affect both as in previous titles. Instead you have a 50/50, or even lower chance with more than two, of stunning the intended enemies; which is very problematic when fighting armored knife wielders. Speaking of armaments, the gadgets aren’t exactly all that interesting or innovative… unless you count the slight improvement to the Explosive Gel which can now actually be shot over short distances. The gadgets are not the only thing on the boring side but the level design is also nothing to write home about. They are repetitive and downright boring.Ultimately, Batman: Arkham Origins – Blackgate is a fun game to play through once or twice but I’d only recommend it for the hardcore fans or those who absolutely love platformers. At the very least I would suggest only picking this title up during one of the many Steam sales for $5.00 because it’s just not worth $19.99, especially when you can grab one of the core Arkham titles for that price instead.-SPARTAN 117 B01

You also might encounter other random B-list villains who are there for their boss fight and nothing else. The plot gives the no reason to be there. Oh sure it makes for criminals to be at a prison but random gigantic zombies with no build-up is where I draw the line. Then there's also Catwoman who Batman caught two weeks before the incident and now mysteriously helps you with no ulterior motive at all. Oh and finally there's some hinting at a Suicide Squad thing just like in Origins, but as of this review it's now the year 2016 and we have no word on anything about that.This game is tedious as all hell. It's structured like a Metroidvania, but it's done so poorly you start wondering if any of the staff even played Super Metroid or Symphone of the Night. Traversing through this horribly-designed areas makes me long for death. What's wrong with it? Let's start with Detective mode. It works like the other games, you activate it with a single button button push, but this time you have to manually scan certain objects with your mouse to check whether you can interact with it or not. You can know the game inside and out, but you will always need to scan it before you can do something that allows you to progress, but this seems to happen selectively depending on the object. This basically means you'll stop dead in your tracks everytime to scan that darn wall just one more time to make sure you can't blow it up. I hope you don't mind this, because you probably will have to leave an area and going to a part you haven't explored yet, because you'll find you don't have the item you need. To be fair, the game most of the time tells you where to go and just not how to get there unless it glitches out and it doesn't appear on the map which has actually happened to me. It's still frustrating to have your progress come to a complete halt, because you don't have a certain utility weapon or missed scanning something. This brings us to exploring. You're always stuck on a 2D plane, however you'll find you can go to different directions with vents or using your grappling hook to get to the background or suddenly the room decides there will be a sharp turn you can take. This doesn't sound too bad, but it makes the map look like an absolute cluster♥♥♥♥. You'll check it every five seconds to make sure you're not heading the wrong way, but it won't help you get into certain rooms, because of some doors are unmarked and rooms with multiple floors are confusing as hell. God forbid you backtrack and forgot how to progress in the room, because of the lack of visual indicators or a helpful map. It doesn't help that the game's levels have no real visual identity and that Batman walks very slowly. To top it all off, there are so many times when a room just locks you out. What I mean by this is that sometimes the game will arbitrarily decide to not let you backtrack the way you came. For example if you use your grappling hook to reach a certain ledge, there's a chance the game won't let you go back by gliding. This means taking a huge detour everytime to go back where you started. Hope you didn't miss anything.Let's talk about the controls. This game feels horrible. Combat just feels sluggish.. I refuse to believe you can pull off crazy combos like in the other Arkham games. Batmans range for punches and kicks isn't consistent, sometimes hits won't connect and counters flat-out don't work half the time. Not that the game is impossibly hard or anything, because the game is very generous with health and doesn't throw tons of enemies at you all at once. Stealth isn't much better. There are usually only three for each section and your options are severely limited. It works, but it's watered down. Bosses are the worst aspect of the game. They're deceptively simple, but have little indicators to teach you how they're supposed to work. Penguin is the worst example as he summons goons that can only be taken out in a specific way. If you don't know to beat them, they're practically invincible and will kill you very quickly.Besides that there really isn't that much to talk about. The music is generic and I don't want to say anything about the graphics because it's a port of a handheld game anyway. Mooks look less like zombies in this version at least, but I still don't get the cutscenes. Why does nobody look like their in-game model? WHO DREW THESE?So in conclusion this game is bad. Don't waste your money. You're better off with Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. Heck even Arkham Knight and Origins are options.

												A mostly good game with some serious issues.For the most part, this is a fun take on the Arkham games. You feel like Batman, and the combat has a similar free-flowing mechanic from the "big" games (although it IS different). The gadgets also all work as they should.However, this game suffers from not knowing if it wants to be 2D, or 3D. Let me explain. The game is a 2D sidescroller: you move on a certain path, and always go left to right. But here they got creative, and added multiple routes that can make you change direction, for example by entering a vent. And this leads to very confused navigation.The in-game map is nearly useless. Because Batman changes direction automatically while moving, you need to constantly check on the map where you are now headed, and since it is drawn on an angle to begin with, with overlapping segments, you WILL get lost.I also got stuck multiple times. There are moments where the plot forces you go go to a certain area which ends in a blocked door, because you do not have the proper gadget yet, and it expects you to find the one spot in several screens that can be bombed to create an opening.Remember how in e.g. Zelda any wall that can be bombed is marked with cracks? Not in this game. You must enter inspection mode, and literally sweep the entire screen of multiple rooms in the hope of finding the one spot which is "structurally weak", so you can progress.The story is weak. You have three opponents, one opponent-slash-ally, and then they suddenly throw in Solomon Grundy... for a single fight, with no build-up whatsoever. The only reason Grundy seems to be thrown in is to emulate the Killer Croc fight from the first Arkham game.I like the graphics, at their best they look very much like the big games. But the cutscenes are done in a highly distorted comic style, which really don't fit the look of the rest of the game. They would have been a lot better if they had been done in-engine, there are a number of "cinematic" scenes that are done this way and those look pretty amazing.And while the voice acting is top notch, there is no lip sync whatsover: characters either "talk" in the cutscenes, which are little more than moving comic panels, or in-game, where their mouths never move.Pick this up if you like Arkham Origins and want more, but skip it if you're not a huge fan of the game series. If this were a numeric review, I'd give it a 6//10.

												This is a Batman metroidvania, and if you like both of those, it can be an enjoyable game.If you only like Batman, you're probably checking this game out as a fan of the Arkham series. Just know that this game is Arkham in name only. Blackgate is a 2.5D exploration platformer, not a 3D third person game like the rest of the series. If you aren't a fan of metroidvanias, this game is definately not going to win you over. The story is very dull, and overly simplistic. Basically there is an explosion at Blackgate and now the criminals are running the place. That's pretty much it as far as the story goes, sadly. As metroidvanias go, the game mechanics are very weak, due to linear level design, and uninspired combat. If you aren't a Batman fan, you'll probably get bored quickly with the repetitive levels and linear flow. I really can't recommend this game on it's mechanics alone.If you happen to like Batman, and you like metroidvanias, Blackgate just might have enough to merit a purchase. The entire game environment is rendered in 3D, despite movement being locked to 2.5D. It's doesn't look as good as the main Arkham games, but it doesn't look like a Vita port either, probably somewhere in between. The environments are actually rendered with a very high attention to detail, especially for a 2.5D game. Some people have had issues with the controls. I played through using a gamepad and had zero issues. Probably the best thing about this game is the animatics created by Calum Alexander Watt and Armature Studio.  You can see several examples here[conceptartworld.com]. As I said before, the mechanics aren't the greatest, but if you like metroidvanias, there might be enough nooks and cranies to explore, collectibles, and upgrades to unlock, to keep you going between animatics.Marking this as "recommened" for the niche audience that the game was made for. Everyone else should look elsewhere.Don't pay more than: $10

												Considering the technical limitations 1) must be mostly 2D interactions, but not always 2) must have been able to run on a handheld and relatively easily upgraded to beefier platforms .... I have been extremely impressed in my first few hours with the game.It's not as good as the other games (of course), but that's impossible with these limitations. However, the combat is fun if somewhat limited, there's lots of batclawing, exploding, detective moding, exploring and whatnot. There's not the open-world flying, but Arkham Asylum didn't really have that either.  The odd thing is that this one has more of an explorative... mazelike... dungeon feel to it, which I thought was pretty cool/fun.  It is closer to Arkham Asylum than the other, open-world game.  Which I don't think is necessarily bad, just different.I do see why people would not recommend it, since the other games are all better (because they didn't have to run on a handheld). However, if you've already played all the other ones (Asylum, City, and Origins), then this one should be next on your list to play IMO because it really is a good game. It's definitely a batman game :)SIDE NOTE JUST IN CASE A DEV READS THIS: The main two things that would need changing (which I think would still let it run on a handheld) would be (A) fully rotatable map on all axis, and (B) minor tweaks to detective scan mode, (C) quicker restarts for boss fights.(A) The map is set currently in an isometric locked view, which has limitations when showing the map from the perspective of the user, height of objects, and depth in complex situations (like a large sprawling map). I really like that the maps are huge and complex, and I don't really have that big of a problem reading the map (but probably because I use Computer Aided Drafting a lot), but I can see it being very difficult for many people to use.(B) Currently, the detective mode only highlights main, mostly obvious items in the environment (switches, thugs, keypads, doors, stuff like that). To find explodables, blood, or some collectables, you have to hold down the detective button and it scans in a circle. There needs to be an upgrade somewhere in the game (and maybe there is) that enlargens the circle and speeds up the scanning speed by at least 2 times the speed. These are really my only two complaints about the game that would be fixable within the technical limitations. I think that's pretty good considering it ran on a handheld.  Don't get me wrong, I do not want you to just change it to how the other games have it.  I actually do not like having to be in detective mode so much, so that's why I like the scanning function, but it needs to be faster and more responsive is all (even if it's 33% into the game).(C) For boss fights, when you have to try them multiple times, you are forced to not only skip the boss intro cinematic, but also watch the first part of the boss intro that is unskippable (which is not long).  On normal fights with previously seen and predictable components, this is fine.  However, all of the boss fights have a "figure it out" part to them (which I don't mind), but having to repeat much of the fight which I have already seen/dealt with does get frustrating since each of the bossfights have a "OH that's what I should do..." moment.  At that point, the player just wants to dive back in quickly and try it again.I'm only mentioning these things though, because I'm hopeful that there will be a sequel that incorporates these elements, because I would totally buy it for PC :)   I was reluctant because of the bad PC reviews, but I was very glad I didn't skip this one.Also I saw some videos of the handheld version, and you guys did a great job upgrading it to be closer to a PC gamer fidelity.  I know some people complained about the graphics, but I thought they were fine for what you were working with (and I know they are just longing for the other Batman game's graphics).

												    Let me get straight down to it: this game sucks. It is a waste of time, money, effort, and constantly frustrates you if you're an Arkham fan.    For some reason, they decided to make it so you control Batman FROM THE SIDE like some kind of Mario side-scroller game, making it IMPOSSIBLE to be stealthy as well as hiding enemies from your line of sight while you're traveling so that they can jump you.    Not only that, but the "cutscenes" are just lame little comic book pictures with a moving hand here or a cigarette with smoke that moves there. It makes you feel completely disconnected from the story as every other moment is interrupted by one of these so-called "cutscenes." As if not feeling like Batman could be in danger wasn't already disconnected!    One of my biggest beefs was the first boss fight. It threw you in there with a comic book cutscene, then said, "Have at it!" without giving you ANY advice whatsoever, expecting you to KNOW how to beat him - with your 5 basic moves... It took me a few tries on NORMAL to figure out what to do, each time having to wait 10 seconds to skip the annoying cutscene.     Another beef I have is that the game STARTS with a cutscene - so you KNOW it's probably going to be a bad game. After the intro cutscene, you jump right in to a fight with some security guards as Catwoman escapes from her most recent burglary.     Then, you have to follow her around - which is quite difficult given the 2D atmosphere yet making you make choices as if it were 3D (grappling onto something in the background, for instance). You finally capture her and send her to Blackgate, which then gets taken over by the Joker, Black Mask, and Penguin. So you go there and work out a deal to team up with her (though you never play as her or see her except in the comic cutscenes), and start beating stuff up.    In fact, that's all this game is. You follow the yellow-brick road since you're practically NAILED to it - no free movement whatsoever - and beat up stuff along the way in a weird attempt at the Super Mario Bros. meets Prison Break.    Now, I know I sound really harsh, but trust me - I'm practically UNDER-exaggerating the crud this game hands to you. I even gave it the benefit of the doubt - I truly hoped it would get better - and gave it about an hour's try. Now I wish I had that hour back, along with my $20 and 2 GB of Hard Drive Disc space. Yeah, it's only 2 GB (other Arkham games range in the late 20's). That can give you an idea about how much - or should I say, how little - the content is in this game.RATING: 1 star (out of 10)

												I am a huge fan of Rocksteady's 'Batman: Arkham' games, but I don't have the urge to play 'Batman: Arkham Origins' at the time of this review as I feel that I don't really need to play a prequel to fully appreciate what Rocksteady has created so far. Plus honestly, I am not ready to spend more than 40 hours playing a reportedly mediocre open-world third-person action game when I already have a backlog of games to get through.However, I decided to give 'Batman: Arkham Origins Blackgate' (AOB) a try as it looked like an accessible Batman game that I could play intermittently until the release of 'Batman: Arkham Knight'. (The low price point was appealing, too.) Sad to say, I found myself feeling underwhelmed with what I played. The pairing of anime-style cutscenes and 2.5D in-game graphics, while looking fantastic in the trailer, proved to be a mismatch. The 'Metroid'-like side-scrolling gameplay also failed to create an immersive environment and somehow made me feel lost most of the time.The 2.5D graphics looked dated despite some remastering for this PC port, and they proved to be the game's undoing as well. I was never quite sure where I could use my grapple gun, drop down a ledge and throw my Batarang without the help of on-screen notifications. Because of that, what could have been great puzzles to solve ended up being hand holding the player through a series of now mundale challenges and quick time events. Plus, needing to use Detective Vision to identify hotspots prior to using some of my gadgets interrupted the flow of the game.I wanted to finish 'AOB' to see the entire story through, but then I realized the story was pretty much the one from 'Arkham Asylum', but done poorly. I saw no signs of story or character development six hours into the game. 'AOB' was unnecessary in the 'Arkham' mythos that Rocksteady had created. After I decided to suffer through the remainder of the game, it crashed and I lost my save file. (Yes, the game failed to save my game properly as well.) I took that as a sign to not waste my time with 'AOB' and to wait patiently for 'Arkham Knight' instead.

The 'Metroid'-like side-scrolling gameplay also failed to create an immersive environment and somehow made me feel lost most of the time.The 2.5D graphics looked dated despite some remastering for this PC port, and they proved to be the game's undoing as well. I was never quite sure where I could use my grapple gun, drop down a ledge and throw my Batarang without the help of on-screen notifications. Because of that, what could have been great puzzles to solve ended up being hand holding the player through a series of now mundale challenges and quick time events. Plus, needing to use Detective Vision to identify hotspots prior to using some of my gadgets interrupted the flow of the game.I wanted to finish 'AOB' to see the entire story through, but then I realized the story was pretty much the one from 'Arkham Asylum', but done poorly. I saw no signs of story or character development six hours into the game. 'AOB' was unnecessary in the 'Arkham' mythos that Rocksteady had created. After I decided to suffer through the remainder of the game, it crashed and I lost my save file. (Yes, the game failed to save my game properly as well.) I took that as a sign to not waste my time with 'AOB' and to wait patiently for 'Arkham Knight' instead.

												I finished up Origins and picked this up for $5 just to keep the ball rolling. Honestly, I can say I shouldn't have bothered. I don't know what it was like before the "deluxe" upgrade, but this version certainly doesn't help much either. Perhaps if this had been the original game that started it all (then jumped to 3D with Asylum) a lot of the game's problems wouldn't be seen as such and it could've been a overwhelming good time. As it is now, the game is basically a regressed version of the series, plagued with too many fun sucking aspects, ranging from plain annoyances to full on boneheaded (spike strips).Story:+Comic cutscenes are nice-Story itself wasn't anything specialCombat:-All that you may be familiar with has been stripped away: speed, precision, quickfire gadgets, even the freaking slide tackle is gone! Throughout the whole game I would still instinctively try to pull these things off during combat to no avail because the actions are so ingrained in me.-Enemies freely move in and out of your plane, causing you to miss sometimes. Other times, Batman doesn't focus on the right target, which at worst case scenario leads to you hurting yourself by attacking a stun baton wielding enemy head on.-Boss fights, while unique, don't offer much to delight in as they are simple and quickly over. Platforming/Exploration:+The only change to the formula I did like was the new cryptographic hacking. Instead of twiddling the sticks to form words in the other games, here you have a grid of numbers that you move a box over to match up a 3 digit sequence.+Lots of areas to cover-Lack of quick exit/travel to the 3 main branches of the prison. Later on there are a couple of shortcuts that will take you from one to another but they aren't labeled on the map in any noticeable way so you'll probably have a difficult time remember them.-Map can be confusing at times since it isn't rotatable and multiple pathways will overlap each other-Spike strips on the floor. Really, who in their right mind came up with this genius obstacle? Sorry, player, we're going to make it travel even more of a chore by having you need to keep your eyes out for these instead of being able to tune out while you only want to get from one end of the room to the other. And naturally since Batman is just starting out and hasn't yet trained a day in his life, he can't merely hop over these tiny hindrances. Instead you have to double tap the button to roll over and avoid damage. If this causes you to exit and delete the game in the first 15 minutes, I completely understand (I'm dead serious, these things are pure garbage.) If you're really dying for more Batman after the main games (and at this time before Arkham Knight's release) then you could go for this at a budget price. I did though and throughout I didn't feel it was worth the time.

Aside from the exploration, I found the story enjoyable, it’s there but it doesn't affect the gameplay too much. Posted: October 23, 2014
												A spin-off of Batman: Arkham Origins, this is a 2.5D action platformer set in the same world as the other Arkham games. While the level design is fairly well done and the game does a good job of providing Metroidvania-esque exploration, it fails in almost every other way. First off, while the level design is good, the navigation is a pain. The "world" is split into three maps, which you have to enter/exit from the front door/back door, which are not easily accessible from most of the map, causing a large portion of backtracking to be for the sole purpose of leaving your current area. To complicate things further, the map is very poorly displayed, particularly in regards to areas with multiple height levels, which can make finding your way around extremely obnoxious.The freeflow combat from the previous games is forced into the 2D perspective, which makes targeting enemies impossible, (you can only attack people directly in front or behind you) and often times they will strafe into the foreground or background which makes it difficult, sometimes literally impossible, to hit them. The predator aspect has almost been entirely removed for this game, and when it does show up, performs terribly, as without the three dimensional movement, there is no way to hide or sneak about other than running away.In addition, blocks/counters don't seem to register half the time and there are no rebindable controls, with the default controls being incredibly odd, making controlling an issue on top of the gameplay issues. In regards to plot, it is extremely simple and is told in such a simple way that you'll get the same level of investment in the game from reading a paragraph long summary of the plot on Wikipedia. In short, I highly recommend that even avid Batman fans avoid this game, as you'll only be disappointed at best, absolutely infuriated at worst.

												I do recommend this game, but my "yes" comes with several caveats.First and foremost this is a 2.5D metroidvania (read, NOT the same gameplay experience as the other Arkham games).  It has the feel and look of the arkham games, and while the combat is similarl its much more restrictive and unimportant (fights are few and far between and not terribly challenging, even the bosses can be easily downed by learning their pattern).  You'll spend most of your time exploring 2.5D environments hunting for upgrades and collectibles and exploring the large environment.  There are 3 major areas each with a boss at the end, and the game can play out very different depending on the order you choose.  The game isn't particularly long so its recommended (and necessary for all achievements) to play through the game 3 times to get all the endings and unlockables.Most of the problems with this game come from its 3DS/Vita origins.  The graphics are extremely and noticeably subpar, with most of the graffity on the prison walls extremely blurry, and batman himself looking decidedly low res.  Additionally, the controls are a bit dodgy.  I got through the entirety of the game using the keyboard and mouse without much trouble, though sometimes counters didn't register.  On the final boss I was stuck for ages because my counters weren't registering in time, until I finally tried using the keyboard to counter instead of the mouse, upon doing this I cleared the fight no problem.  Lastly, the game is short.  My first playthrough clocked in at near 11 hours, then my subsequent 2 to get all the achievements took about 5 a piece.  That being said, the game didn't overstay its welcome and anything more might have felt like padding.I enjoyed this game, as a fan of Arkham and Metroid there was a lot to be had here, and I hope they improve upon this idea for future endeavors.  That being said, I got the game very cheap during the Steam summer sale, and suggest you do the same as at present the full price of the game just isn't quite worth it.

												I own this title on two platforms; the original 3DS and PC.For those of you wondering if this is just another game in the now legendary Arkham series I must tell you that it is not. There are certain elements of the gameplay that are similar, but as it was developed for the 3DS, it does not play like the other games in the series. Batman; Arkham Origins Blackgate (BAOB) is quite unique both in the artwork used for the cutscenes and in the battle and weapons interfaces. The cutscenes are done in a cell-shading style seemingly used to create more of a comic book effect. I don't mean to say anything disparaging about the the artist, but I am not a fan. I do appreciate the talent and effort required to produce such work, but it's just not my cup of tea.The gameplay is fair. It's hard to judge based on a familiarity with the other games in the series. The processing power of a 3DS obviously could not handle a game like the others in the series. The developers created a sort of hybrid interface, which at times works very well, and some of the battles are quite enjoyable. The problems, in my opinion, are not based so much in the combat as in the interaction with the evironment, which comprises most of the gameplay. As Batman explores Blackgate prison he typically moves from side to side as in a classic side-scroller like Super Mario Brothers, only path will often have several layers, requiring button prompts to appear on the screen to allow the player to move Batman from one layer, or path if you will, to another. This can often become very tedious and sometimes clunky. The various overlapping paths can also render the map, which can be accessed in a sub-menu, virtually useless. It can be very easy to get lost as you crawl through various vents, turn corners, and drop from the ceiling into rooms. The story told by the forementioned cutscenes is engaging as Batman encounters Catwoman, presumably for the first time, and is pulled into a mystery that seems to take place sometime between Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. A few of  Batman's well-known adversaries must be defeated as Batman tries to regain control of the prison. It is a good game, but not a great game. Certainly a must-have for a real Batman fan, but probably not recommended for the average gamer.7/10

												If you're a fan of Metroidvania games and the Batman Arkham franchise then this is an excellent game for you.  You have a fairly big, complex, and non-linear map to explore.  There are plenty of unlockables to discover including access codes for new areas, upgrades for gadgets, and character skins.  There are also many hidden collectables for rewards too.The combat is pretty good but, as this is a port from the Nintendo DS, it is not a deep as the other Arkham games.  However, enemy encounters are varied as you are put in different situations and can use the environment to your advantage such pulling away weak supports with your batclaw or cutting down hanging lights with your batarang.  You can still sneak around and perform a variety takedowns or swoop from above.  Boss fights are entertaining and varied but there are not that many as there is only one per main area.  The puzzles are good and pretty challenging as you would expect from a game originally designed for NDS gameplay.  The only real down side to this game is that scanning the environments can be tedious at times as you will need to unlock new paths and find hidden items.  Even though there is some form of fast travel for previously explore areas with unlocked elevator, you will need to backtrack quite a bit.  This is not always a bad thing as you can unlock new items you've missed and get surprised with new enemies.  Also, there are a few frustrating moments which only occur when you don't know how to solve a puzzle, approach a difficult boss, or disarm some bombs later on in the game.The graphics have been upgraded for this version but there's still room for improvement with the textures when seen upclose which is normally when the game zooms in as Batman takes down his last foe in slow motion.  The sound, music, and voice acting is top notch as aways with this franchise.  The cutscenes are in a stylish motion comic form which I assume is feature derived from being a NDS port but they are still good quality and entertaining.The story itself is very good and serves as a good side-story / follow-up to Arkham Origins.  Some new characters are introduced but are not seen as often as you would like.  Surprisingly, the ending will leave you wanting more as some mysteries are left to be unravelled for another time.This is a very good game overall.  It only received hate for being a 2.5D game but if that doesn't bother you then don't miss out on a good story and great action.  Depending on the type of player you are the game can take 6-10 hours to beat on a regular play through, and 15-20 hours if you are trying to 100% the entire game.  My playthrough was inbetween as it took me 14.5 hours.  I tried to be quick but I did get distracted by searching for some unlockables.This game is a must have for fans of the Batman Arkham franchise as well as 2.5D Metroidvania lovers.  If this game is on sale you can't go wrong.

												I recommend this game for anyone who is a fan of Batman Arham Universe and wants to complement his experience after playing Arkham Origins. The first hour into the game was the most difficult for me, because I'm not used to this 2.5 D environments. The controls were intuitive and easy for me. The graphics looks great compared to PS Vita, but they are out of the league of the other Arkham games. It's worth the time and the money, considering that is a companion game. The game is sure full of content, with some side missions desguised as Detective cases. The game is item based, meaning that you don't earn experience for what you do, but you rather collect items scathered around the map to get upgrades and more batsuits. Ezio is again impersonating Batman, and the Joker, Pinguin and Black Mask returns as villains. This is the first time that Ezio faces Catwoman as a villain. Her boss figth is short and sweet. Other boss figths count on you having perfect timing and lateral thinking. They take just one to five minutes to complete. This game again replicates the sins of his predecessors. Backtracking. You run, and run and run  from room to room to collect items that are necessary to your quest. Fights are scarce, and the predator sections of the game fails miserably to entertain. I just wanted to get over with those parts and continuining my violent tour in Blackgate, that is remiscient to the first time I toured Arkham Asylum. A lot of walking. Exploring is supossed to be rewarding, but the 2.5 D environment makes the experience less inmersive, and is not very enjoyable. I got used to the map and that made my life a lot easier. This a flawed yet entertaining game, that complements the Arham experience. Is worth the full price compared to DLCs or other titles in line with the same price point, and if you are Batman fan. There was certainly a lot of heart and effort in this title to make it a complete experience, that can stand on his own. It takes five to ten hours to complete the first run, and another five to ten to get all collectables and finish the Plus mode.

What went rightImproved backtracking -There are multiple ways of exiting each zone and it's relatively quick to do so. I understand this wasn't present in the original mobile version.Distinct Batsuits - It isn't a case of Arkham Origins itself, with its Batman in a different costume which can look out of place and at-odds with Arkham City's Batsuits having unique heads/bodies. Although some appear to be straight ports with detail removed, such as AO's and Red Son's suits, the others in AO Blackgate are built just for this and usually offer some gameplay benefit. The pseudo-motion comics work well, though the in-game cutscenes are unskippable.Detective mode is sort-of improved. I like the circle allowing focus on specific areas, I don't like the repeated "analyzing" animation for things such as exploding walls, Batman should know immediately after scanning the first one to know what he's looking at.What went wrongPretty much everything else...Boss fights can have good ideas, but are poorly executed overall. If this wasn't a 2.5D platformer, and was Arkham City instead, the boss fights would be over in one fell swoop. I also found only the boss fight with The Penguin to auto-save your progress, so as to retry with The Penguin at his reduced health and in the final stage of the fight. The rest seemingly don't have that luxury, forcing you to go over the same stages again. The final boss fight itself has a novel twist let down by......The Infamous Clunky Controls - This is not a smooth experience. Arkham Origins' movement and combat itself was, dare I say it, a hit and miss affair and not even as smooth as the original Arkham Asylum. Here? It's even worse.  Countering using the mouse often doesn't register, which is not so bad when fighting mooks but the final boss fight with Catwoman makes the game an exercise in frustration and rage (making that novel twist all for naught).  The keyboard works better, but unless you have a mechanical keyboard such as I do, it'd be cheaper (!) and possibly better to use a gamepad (and, of course, not everyone has a gamepad attached to the PC!).The boss dialogue is repeitive at best. The Penguin will repeatedly announce "you hit like a ponce!" when Batman is standing still (or otherwise not fighting), and other such lines from a very limited pool of material every few seconds. I get the impression that the dialogue was designed for specific gameplay events (e.g. perhaps Batman not getting a high freeflow count), rather than the dialogue being rattled off ad nauseum.The 2.5D platforming self-sabotages from the get-go. Situations with mooks could be sorted out in moments within Arkham City, but here? You may end up unable to grapple from vantage point to vantage point for seemingly no reason, or have to move the mouse cursor over the grapple point in case of standing in an area with two or more possibilities. Worse when you have to be in a particular spot.  Sometimes running (pressing space) can mean Batman interacting with the environment when you don't want him to. Other times, he just doesn't register counter button presses to literally save himself.Other than that, stealth moves can be finnicky - such as performing a floor grate takedown, where you have to be facing the right direction and be exactly under the grate behind the mook. Guns are almost instant kills and Batman still hasn't sorted out his rebreather (used in a cutscene) to filter out such gas. So it ends up being the old chestnut of a meter that quickly fills up and dissipates if you get out of the gas infested area in time.The story is adequate but not enough to divert from the bad points. To be honest, this could have been RIddler's chance to shine as the main villain, but the villains chosen make more sense for marketing purposes than gameplay purposes. The Joker is the only one with a boss fight that entirely feeds off his character, with the last boss fight only partially using unique character traits (the other parts of that boss fight being repeats of what had gone before). The other main and secondary bosses are either retreads or generic waves of henchmen and drop down on the boss (think Catwoman vs Two-Face at the end of Arkham City).The A.I. knows where you are, and will cheat - if you're spotted in a boss fight, the henchmen know precisely where you are, even when you've moved to the opposite side of the screen and avoided any further detection. Batman usually moves so slowly, that they can catch up with him relatively easily.In closing...The map can be confusing, the graphics are recycled (including animations) but with less shaders and reduced resolution for the textures (given the mobile devices the game was originally intended for) and this let's the game down when played on the PC. But it's the die-hard Arkham fan that I recommend this for, but do wait for a sale (I bought my copy from the Humble Store on sale) and you should get 7-10 hours of determined enjoyment out of it. Otherwise, get a gamepad and buy the Lego Batman games/replay the Rocksteady-made Arkham games/replay Arkham Origins/wait for Arkham Knight.

												I do recommend this game, but my "yes" comes with several caveats.First and foremost this is a 2.5D metroidvania (read, NOT the same gameplay experience as the other Arkham games).  It has the feel and look of the arkham games, and while the combat is similarl its much more restrictive and unimportant (fights are few and far between and not terribly challenging, even the bosses can be easily downed by learning their pattern).  You'll spend most of your time exploring 2.5D environments hunting for upgrades and collectibles and exploring the large environment.  There are 3 major areas each with a boss at the end, and the game can play out very different depending on the order you choose.  The game isn't particularly long so its recommended (and necessary for all achievements) to play through the game 3 times to get all the endings and unlockables.Most of the problems with this game come from its 3DS/Vita origins.  The graphics are extremely and noticeably subpar, with most of the graffity on the prison walls extremely blurry, and batman himself looking decidedly low res.  Additionally, the controls are a bit dodgy.  I got through the entirety of the game using the keyboard and mouse without much trouble, though sometimes counters didn't register.  On the final boss I was stuck for ages because my counters weren't registering in time, until I finally tried using the keyboard to counter instead of the mouse, upon doing this I cleared the fight no problem.  Lastly, the game is short.  My first playthrough clocked in at near 11 hours, then my subsequent 2 to get all the achievements took about 5 a piece.  That being said, the game didn't overstay its welcome and anything more might have felt like padding.I enjoyed this game, as a fan of Arkham and Metroid there was a lot to be had here, and I hope they improve upon this idea for future endeavors.  That being said, I got the game very cheap during the Steam summer sale, and suggest you do the same as at present the full price of the game just isn't quite worth it.

												I own this title on two platforms; the original 3DS and PC.For those of you wondering if this is just another game in the now legendary Arkham series I must tell you that it is not. There are certain elements of the gameplay that are similar, but as it was developed for the 3DS, it does not play like the other games in the series. Batman; Arkham Origins Blackgate (BAOB) is quite unique both in the artwork used for the cutscenes and in the battle and weapons interfaces. The cutscenes are done in a cell-shading style seemingly used to create more of a comic book effect. I don't mean to say anything disparaging about the the artist, but I am not a fan. I do appreciate the talent and effort required to produce such work, but it's just not my cup of tea.The gameplay is fair. It's hard to judge based on a familiarity with the other games in the series. The processing power of a 3DS obviously could not handle a game like the others in the series. The developers created a sort of hybrid interface, which at times works very well, and some of the battles are quite enjoyable. The problems, in my opinion, are not based so much in the combat as in the interaction with the evironment, which comprises most of the gameplay. As Batman explores Blackgate prison he typically moves from side to side as in a classic side-scroller like Super Mario Brothers, only path will often have several layers, requiring button prompts to appear on the screen to allow the player to move Batman from one layer, or path if you will, to another. This can often become very tedious and sometimes clunky. The various overlapping paths can also render the map, which can be accessed in a sub-menu, virtually useless. It can be very easy to get lost as you crawl through various vents, turn corners, and drop from the ceiling into rooms. The story told by the forementioned cutscenes is engaging as Batman encounters Catwoman, presumably for the first time, and is pulled into a mystery that seems to take place sometime between Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. A few of  Batman's well-known adversaries must be defeated as Batman tries to regain control of the prison. It is a good game, but not a great game. Certainly a must-have for a real Batman fan, but probably not recommended for the average gamer.7/10

Save your money and don't waste your time.

The controls are a mess too, and so sometimes you need to hold "A" to enter a vent, sometimes its Down + "A", sometimes the Right Trigger button or sometimes its Down + Right Trigger. When you are trying to escape an enemy with a gun, you can be pressing the buttons you usually press to get away, but this particular room might have a completely differnt set of buttons. It really is just a mess. The combat is repetitive and boring too. You can start a combo on an enemy and rather than seeing different attacks, Batman just throws the same punch over and over again until the final blow (which does differ). It just feels really lacking compared the real Arkham Games. Another thing which is overdone and frustrating is the constant back tracking. You need to enter each wing to get a piece of Bat-Tech for the next wings Puzzle, but then have to re-enter them to get the access codes and then re-enter each one again to fight the bosses. Finally you have to re-enter them yet again because you have to disarm some Bombs which have been placed right in the dead centre of each zone. In all honesty, this game would probably last an hour if you didn't have to back track so much. It's pretty clear to me that they have just added the back-tracking in to ensure the game has a longer play time, but for me it wasn't fun, it was very boring and very frustrating getting lost constantly. I have loved all of the Arkham games and DLC and even though this was a side scroller beat em up, I wanted to love it too but I just can't. I honestly have more fun playing an old 80's side scroller like Streets of Rage or Final Fight than I had during the several hours this took to complete. I feel bad leaving this review if I am honest, but I just can't say anything nice about this game. Even the story itself is pretty bland and doesn't make much sense. I wanted to play it because I had heard it bridged the gap between Arkham origins and Arkham Asylum, but to be truthful I could have easily never played this and still felt like the games bridged by themselves. The story just doesn't link the games for me, and it made the overall frustration factor even worse because I might as well have not wasted my time. I honestly wouldn't recommend buying this game. If you get it free from a Bundle of the other Arkham games, then sure give it a play. But honestly, I regret buying this game.

No Wonder They Moved Out Of BlackgateIf Steam had the opportunity to give out 'Average' or 'Meh' ratings, I'd give it to this game. Whenever this game gets something right, it gets something else wrong. Good, simple controls get muddled by bad enemy selection and counter response time. Boss fights with iconic characters are almost always turned into annoying battles in which you die in stupid ways because the game fails to telegraph where the boss can actually see you. However the game does have some merits, so by all means read on!GameplayBlackgate is unlike the other Batman: Arkham series. It's a 2.5D side-scrolling adventure with platforming puzzles and occasional beat-em-ups. It's been proven in one of Arkham City's DLCs that sidescrolling Arkham combat works. Sadly I had terrible problems with the way that Batman selects who he's fighting. His cape stun, which normally should 'follow' enemies, simply extends to a small range just in front of Batman. When I ask Batman to counter, there is a terrible delay of roughly a second, which generally translates to Batman getting slogged in the back of the head.There are puzzles to solve with your gadgets, which are generally simple and relatively easy to solve. However it's a welcome change from Blackgate's clumsy combat system. There are lots of platforming opportunities which are good and generally easily accessible, except for one particularly frustrating jump toward the end of the game in the Arkham Wing. All in all I enjoyed the traversing and movement systems. There are only two bosses that I enjoyed (The Joker and Solomon Grundy). Other than that, the other bosses were either infuriating/annoying or poorly made (Black Mask, Penguin, Catwoman) or they were pathetically easy (Bronze Tiger, Deadshot). StoryBatman captures Catwoman and chucks her into Blackgate. A couple of weeks later, there's a big old riot down at Blackgate. Batman must swoop in and recapture the three big crime bosses. Familiar? It does have some good moments. The big draw of the story is to see the first encounter between Batman and Catwoman, and if you're a fan of Catwoman you'll like this story. An enjoyable, if somewhat predictable, story. Graphics, Atmosphere and SoundHonestly, no wonder everyone ditched Blackgate! The only really well done thing in terms of graphics are the character models for main characters, the cutscenes and some details in the environment. My main gripe is that essentially everything is brown and grey. The colour palette is incredibly sparse. No wonder the prisoners revolted; the place is outright depressing. The cutscenes are of a comic-book style which I really enjoyed watching as the story unfolded. Thug character models are pretty much all identical in terms of their archetype. Yes, I understand that it was a PS Vita game. But it was. Surely they could've done something more to make it better looking for the PC players!I guess they nailed the atmosphere of a prison. I almost wished that they'd spiced up the look of it in some places, but if you're looking for a dirty prison vibe this game really nails it. In terms of sound, the game does it well. With good background music (that I think's been taken from Arkham Origins) and good voice acting all around, as well as the thumping of fists onto faces, they've done that really well. ConclusionBlackgate is about 50/50. The graphics aren't really up to standard in my opinion and the map... it's quite possibly the most annoying looking map I've ever come across through gaming. It's a 3D map filled with passages, pathways and dotted lines and it's hard to make heads or tails of it. But Blackgate has a good story, some good platforming and puzzles and sound design. It's a game that I most certainly wouldn't recommend to everyone, and it's obviously a divisive game. But if you're a Batman fan and you're willing to uncover a new story in another broken down prison, this game should suffice to distract you for about seven to eight hours. jmcone's Final Rating- Purchase on Sale

It's a game that I most certainly wouldn't recommend to everyone, and it's obviously a divisive game. But if you're a Batman fan and you're willing to uncover a new story in another broken down prison, this game should suffice to distract you for about seven to eight hours. jmcone's Final Rating- Purchase on Sale

												I don't regret getting this, but I can't rightly recommend it to anyone. It's basically the same formula as Arkham Asylum/City/Origins, but stuffed in a 2.5D game. Where Origins was still good fun even though it felt a bit like the B team had a go at making a Batman game, this game felt like it had the C team work on it.The combat is unsatisfying due to the difficulty in targeting a specific enemy when 3 are lined up along the same height on the screen, which is especially annoying for enemies you need to stun or vault over. It's also hard to keep combos going, since the limited sight range might have you guessing if an offscreen enemy is up yet to recieve a beatdown, or you'll just whiff in place.The map is the most confusing mess I've seen for a game map yet; it's an angled top-down view which is blown up in places and connected with dotted lines. Sometimes areas overlap by being above or behind each other, and it's really not clear what's going on on the map.Detective vision has had a downgrade, and now requires dragging a large cursor over the screen to find interesting things, and then waiting for them to scan. Batman can't move while this goes on. It gets very boring after a few screens.There's an explosive gel launcher, which is a better version of the explosive gel spray. In everything else, it's an extremely stripped down version of any of the Arkham games. The story isn't interesting, the cutscenes are (almost) motionless drawings, and the graphics are worse than Arkham Asylum. Visually recognizable pieces of the world that need a specific gadget to interact with need to be scanned first, no matter how many times you've opened/wrecked exactly the same thing. Bosses frequently introduce new game mechanics that aren't explained. The 2.5D movement makes the whole game feel very constrained, and especially the stealth gameplay suffers for it.On the plus side, it can occasionally look nice, art-direction wise, and there's plenty to explore.
